Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Limits in Ultrafast High Brightness Electron Beam Generation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accelerators are important instruments for the advancement of scientific research, for their broad application in medicine and industry, and as a research area in their own right. Accelerators typically accelerate protons, antiprotons, electrons and positrons (anti-electrons). Powerful accelerators have lead to the discoveries of the Higgs Boson and the top quark, intermediate sized accelerators have been used as sources of x-rays to study properties of materials, and smaller machines are used to provide cancer therapy or for electron beam microscopy.

A recent novel trend in accelerator and beam physics is the development of precise electron beams for diverse applications in the study of ultrafast structural dynamics, and as the drivers for Free Electron Lasers or laser-based accelerators. This award to UCLA aims to develop a new electron source capable of generating electron beams with an order of magnitude higher brightness than has been previously achievable using state-of-the-art radiofrequency photoinjectors. By pushing for lower beam charges, the design choices of a photoinjector cavity can be reevaluated, incorporating recent advances in cathode surface engineering and adopting different solutions for the beam dynamics.

Technically, the development of a novel electron source with extreme beam parameters will have important impact on compact x-ray free-electron lasers and ultrafast electron diffraction and microscopy. These technologies have the prospect to provide real time atomic scale images of matter with the potential for profound impact in a variety of scientific fields such as condensed matter physics, chemistry, biology and material sciences. Educationally, the work with be intrinsically interdisciplinary and will provide full hands-on experience for students with a broad preparation in photoemission physics, laser and accelerator technology, and high brightness beam and beam diagnostic development.

In the program as awarded, the UCLA group plans to study some of the most pressing unanswered questions in electron-source physics, such as the growth of the longitudinal emittance and uncorrelated energy spread and the limit in the cathode thermal emittance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded a research project to explore the limits in the quality of electron beams. Each electron beam application has different requirements on the beam quality, but in order to classify electron sources accelerator physicists typically use a general quantity like the beam brightness, that is the 6D phase space density. For photoemission sources, this quantity depends on the details of the photoemission physics (laser and photocathode surface) and on the electric field initially used to accelerate the electrons.

The major outcomes of the project are the demonstration of very low emittance and ultrashort bunch length using a very small and ultrashort laser pulse to illuminate the cathode in a high field radiofrequency photoinjector and a booster cavity to carry out the beam compression. The bunch was compressed to a duration of less than 10 trillionths of a second which is sufficient to freeze atomic motion when the beam is used in ultrafast electron diffraction experiments (image #1). These results appeared in PRL earlier this year and have been highlighted in an APS Physics Viewpoint (Physics 10,39 2017) 

Other notable results include the development of novel diagnostics to characterize these beams of unprecedented characteristics, (Cesar et al., PRL 2016), a theoretical study of the limit at the photocathode brightness (Maxson et al., PRL 2017) and the design of a novel RF gun (Pirez et al., NIM 2017) with a much larger launch field which has the potential to further improve brightness of future electron sources (image #2).

All of the research was carried out at the UCLA Pegasus laboratory which is a unique student-run university laboratory with a state-of-the-art beam which attracted other users interested in the flexibility and the performance of the beamline. In the last few years, Pegasus has been used in testing novel dielectric laser accelerator structures, developing time-resolved electron microscopy (image #3), and exploring new concepts for pattering the beam at the nanoscale.

The broader impact of the work are related to the formation of a new class of hands-on accelerator scientists (image #4). Three graduate students working on Pegasus are about to graduate. Particular care was put in increasing the diversity of the group which is 40 % female students and postdoc much higher than when we started three years ago (< 10 %). Finally a novel hands-on graduate class on the physics of photoinjector was developed during the course of this project. The course was much appreciated by the students and resulted in a teaching award from the UCLA Physics department.
